description: Understand related addition and subtraction facts within a family

commonMistakes: Not recognizing all four related facts

description: Identify and use relationships between addition and subtraction

coreConcepts: Addition and subtraction are inverse operations
Using known facts to derive new ones

description: Find the unknown addend in addition equations like 5 + __ = 12

coreConcepts: Use subtraction to find missing addend
teachingTips: Think: What do I add to get to...?

description: Solve word problems with unknown addends
Maintain equality on both sides of a balance

coreConcepts: Balance maintained when same added/removed from both sides

description: Understand the meaning of the equal sign as a relation of equivalence
Solve problems with boxes or blanks representing unknown numbers
Use boxes or blanks as placeholders for unknown values (early algebra)
Solve one-step linear equations using inverse operations

coreConcepts: Balance method: same to both sides
commonMistakes: Not doing same to both sides
teachingTips: Think: what operation is done to x?

description: Solve equations of the form x + a = b
Solve equations of the form x - a = b
Solve equations of the form ax = b
Solve equations of the form x/a = b
Solve two-step linear equations like 2x + 3 = 11

coreConcepts: Undo operations in reverse order (PEMDAS backwards)
Typically: undo addition/subtraction first, then multiplication/division

description: Solve equations requiring combining like terms and distribution
Solve equations requiring the distributive property
Solve equations with variables on both sides like 3x + 2 = x + 10

coreConcepts: Get all variables to one side
Get constants to the other side
Special cases: no solution, infinite solutions
commonMistakes: Not moving all variables to same side

description: Solve systems of equations using substitution method

coreConcepts: Solve one equation for one variable
teachingTips: Always check in both original equations

description: Solve systems of equations by adding or subtracting equations

coreConcepts: Add or subtract to eliminate one variable

description: Solve systems by graphing and finding intersection points

coreConcepts: Graph both equations on same axes

description: Identify and understand no solution and infinite solution cases
Add whole numbers fluently
Subtract whole numbers fluently
Count forward from any number
Count backward from any number
Count objects to determine quantity
Count equal groups to find total
Count by 2s, 5s, 10s, etc.
Understand multiplication as equal groups
Interpret 3 × 4 as 3 groups of 4 objects
Multiply single-digit numbers fluently
Add equal groups (introduction to multiplication)
Understand fractions as parts of a whole
Understand 1/4 as one part of four equal pieces
Add fractions with like and unlike denominators
Subtract fractions with like and unlike denominators
Multiply fractions by fractions
Divide fractions by fractions using reciprocals
Simplify expressions by combining like terms
Use properties to generate equivalent expressions
Apply the distributive property to expand and factor expressions
Expand expressions using the distributive property
Understand place value in whole numbers
Break numbers into tens and ones
Combine parts to make wholes
Write numbers in expanded form
Regroup ones as tens, tens as hundreds, etc.
Add multi-digit numbers with regrouping
Understand relationship between parts and whole
Understand addition as putting parts together
Add equal groups to find total
Compare numbers using greater than, less than, equal to
Compare multi-digit whole numbers
Use >, <, = to compare numbers
Understand the equal sign as meaning 'the same as'
Put numbers in order from least to greatest
Understand order relationships among numbers
Round numbers to the nearest ten, hundred, etc.
Round numbers to the nearest ten
Understand ratio concepts and use ratio language

coreConcepts: Ratio notation: a:b, a to b, a/b

description: Identify and evaluate exponential functions f(x) = a·b^x

coreConcepts: a is initial value, b is growth/decay factor
Growth if b > 1, decay if 0 < b < 1
commonMistakes: Mixing up growth factor and rate
teachingTips: Compare table of values: linear vs exponential
Real-world: population growth, compound interest, radioactive decay

description: Evaluate limits using algebraic techniques
Find derivatives using limit definition
Plot and identify points using ordered pairs

coreConcepts: Ordered pair (x, y) where x is horizontal, y is vertical
Four quadrants, x and y axes
commonMistakes: Going up/down first instead of left/right
teachingTips: Remember: 'along the hallway, up the stairs'
Connect to real maps, battleship game

description: Calculate and interpret slope as rate of change

coreConcepts: Slope = rise/run = change in y / change in x
Positive slope rises left to right
Negative slope falls left to right
Zero slope is horizontal, undefined slope is vertical
teachingTips: Connect to real rates: speed, cost per item

description: Factor and simplify rational expressions by canceling common factors

coreConcepts: State domain restrictions (values that make denominator zero)
Simplified form has no common factors
teachingTips: Emphasize: can only cancel FACTORS, never terms
Factor completely first, then look for common factors
Always state what values x cannot equal
Check work by multiplying factors back

description: Multiply rational expressions by multiplying numerators and denominators

coreConcepts: Multiply numerators together, multiply denominators together
teachingTips: Factor FIRST, then cancel, then multiply (less work)
Show connection to multiplying numeric fractions

description: Divide rational expressions by multiplying by the reciprocal

coreConcepts: Keep-Change-Flip: keep first, change ÷ to ×, flip second
commonMistakes: Forgetting restrictions from the flipped fraction
teachingTips: Check: division is multiplication by reciprocal

description: Add and subtract rational expressions using common denominators

teachingTips: LCD is LCM of denominator polynomials
Distribute carefully when rewriting with LCD
Combine ONLY numerators, denominator stays same

description: Prove triangles congruent using postulates

coreConcepts: SAS: two sides and included angle
ASA: two angles and included side
teachingTips: Use color coding for corresponding parts

description: Understand similarity, find scale factors, and solve proportions

coreConcepts: Scale factor = ratio of corresponding sides

description: Solve and graph inequalities including compound inequalities

coreConcepts: Flip inequality when multiplying/dividing by negative

description: Identify patterns, find terms, and sum arithmetic sequences
Work with geometric sequences and find sums, including infinite series
Evaluate definite integrals using Fundamental Theorem of Calculus

commonMistakes: F(a) - F(b) instead of F(b) - F(a)

description: Evaluate and compose functions using proper notation
Calculate and interpret the mean of a data set

coreConcepts: Mean = sum of all values ÷ count
Also called average or arithmetic mean
teachingTips: Real data sets from students lives

description: Find the median (middle value) of a data set

coreConcepts: Order values from least to greatest
Even count: average of two middle values
commonMistakes: Picking wrong middle for even count
teachingTips: Cross off from both ends to find middle

description: Identify the mode (most frequent value) of a data set

coreConcepts: Can have no mode, one mode, or multiple modes
commonMistakes: Thinking there must always be one mode
Finding the highest value instead of most frequent
teachingTips: Tally charts or frequency tables help

description: Calculate the range (spread) of a data set

teachingTips: Connect to everyday language ("range of temperatures")

description: Perform and describe translations (slides) on the coordinate plane

coreConcepts: Translation slides a figure without rotation or flipping
Every point moves the same distance and direction
teachingTips: Use graph paper or coordinate plane
Real: sliding objects, video game sprites

description: Perform and describe reflections (flips) over lines

coreConcepts: Reflection flips a figure over a line (line of reflection)
Each point and its image are equidistant from the line
Preserves size and shape, reverses orientation
commonMistakes: Not preserving distance to line of reflection
Confusing which axis is line of reflection
teachingTips: Count squares from line of reflection
Real: mirror images, symmetry in nature

description: Perform and describe rotations (turns) around a point

coreConcepts: Rotation turns a figure around a center point
Specified by center, angle, and direction (clockwise/counterclockwise)
commonMistakes: Not rotating all points same amount
Forgetting which point is the center
teachingTips: Use tracing paper to physically rotate

description: Describe events as likely or unlikely based on experience

coreConcepts: Likely means it will probably happen
Unlikely means it will probably not happen
Use everyday experiences to make predictions
commonMistakes: Not understanding that unlikely things can still happen
Basing predictions on wishes rather than reality
teachingTips: Use everyday examples: Will it rain? Will you eat lunch today?
Sort event cards into likely/unlikely piles
Connect to weather, daily routines, familiar games
Use picture cards showing different scenarios

description: Use probability vocabulary: certain, likely, unlikely, impossible

coreConcepts: Unlikely: not much chance of happening
Use precise words to describe chance
teachingTips: Create probability word wall with examples
Number line: impossible → unlikely → likely → certain
Spinner activities: which color is most/least likely?
Real contexts: weather, birthdays, coin flips

description: Find probability of simple events using outcomes

commonMistakes: Assuming all outcomes are equally likely when they are not
teachingTips: Use concrete materials: spinners, dice, colored cubes
List all possible outcomes before calculating
Experiments: flip coins, draw from bags
Start with equally likely outcomes only

description: Express probability as fractions (favorable/total)

coreConcepts: Numerator = number of ways event can happen
Denominator = total number of possible outcomes
commonMistakes: Putting total in numerator and favorable in denominator
Thinking probability can be greater than 1
teachingTips: Visual: shade favorable outcomes on diagrams
Connect to real fractions: 3/8 of the spinner is red
Practice with spinners, bags of colored objects

description: Collect and organize data in tables and charts

coreConcepts: Organize data so it is easy to read
commonMistakes: Asking questions that cannot be answered with data
teachingTips: Start with class surveys: favorite color, pet, lunch
Use concrete objects before abstract recording

description: Use tally marks to collect and display data

coreConcepts: One tally mark for each item counted
Cross through four marks for fifth
Easy to count and compare quickly
teachingTips: Count by fives, then add remaining
Use for live data: vehicles passing, birds at feeder

description: Create and interpret frequency tables

coreConcepts: Frequency = how many times each value occurs
teachingTips: Convert tally charts to frequency tables
Ask: Which has most? Least? How many total?
Real data from class or school
Bridge to bar graphs and pictographs

description: Identify and name common 2D and 3D shapes

coreConcepts: Recognize shapes in different orientations and sizes
commonMistakes: Thinking a tilted square is not a square
Not recognizing shapes in different sizes
teachingTips: Shape hunts in classroom and outside
Sort shape cards in different ways
Emphasize: size and orientation don't change the shape

description: Sort and classify shapes based on their attributes

coreConcepts: Attributes: number of sides, corners, faces
Sort by one or more attributes
Same shape can belong to multiple categories
Use describing words: curved, straight, flat, solid
commonMistakes: Thinking shapes can only belong to one group

description: Understand properties of 2D shapes: sides, vertices, angles

coreConcepts: Properties: triangles have 3 sides, quadrilaterals have 4
commonMistakes: Missing vertices or counting them twice
Not recognizing irregular versions of shapes
teachingTips: Build shapes with straws, toothpicks, geoboards

description: Understand properties of 3D shapes: faces, edges, vertices

coreConcepts: Common 3D shapes: cube, sphere, cylinder, cone, pyramid
teachingTips: Count faces, edges, vertices on models

description: Describe position using spatial vocabulary: above, below, beside, in front of, behind

coreConcepts: Relative positions change based on perspective
commonMistakes: Confusing left and right with other positions
Not considering perspective or point of view
Using vague language instead of precise terms
teachingTips: Use toys or blocks to model positions

description: Use positional vocabulary to give and follow directions

coreConcepts: Precise vocabulary: left, right, up, down
Between: position relative to two objects
Combine position words for complex directions
commonMistakes: Not following directions in correct sequence
teachingTips: Grid games: describe how to get from point to point

description: Find area by counting squares or using length × width

coreConcepts: Area measures space inside a shape
Count unit squares to find area
Units are square units (sq cm, sq ft, etc.)
teachingTips: Real contexts: covering a floor, painting a wall
Visual: fill in rectangles on grid paper

description: Find perimeter by adding all side lengths

coreConcepts: Perimeter is distance around a shape
Units are linear units (cm, ft, etc.)
Can find missing side if perimeter is known
commonMistakes: Using square units instead of linear units
teachingTips: Walk around the shape: measure each side
Use string or tape to measure perimeter
Compare: shapes with same area can have different perimeters

description: Solve real-world problems involving area and perimeter

coreConcepts: Identify whether problem asks for area or perimeter
commonMistakes: Finding area when perimeter is needed (or vice versa)
Missing information or assuming square dimensions
teachingTips: Highlight: What does the problem ask for?
Always draw and label a picture
Real projects: design a garden, plan a room
Compare: when do we need area vs perimeter?
Multi-step: find one measure to find the other

description: Identify lines of symmetry in shapes and figures

coreConcepts: Line of symmetry divides shape into two identical halves
Each half is mirror image of the other
Some shapes have multiple lines of symmetry
Some shapes have no lines of symmetry
commonMistakes: Drawing diagonal when not actually symmetrical
Confusing rotational symmetry with line symmetry
Not testing both sides match exactly
teachingTips: Fold paper cutouts to test symmetry
Explore symmetry in letters, shapes, nature
Draw one half, partner completes other half
Count lines of symmetry in regular polygons

description: Work with and analyze symmetric shapes

coreConcepts: Regular polygons have multiple lines of symmetry
commonMistakes: Not recognizing all lines of symmetry
Confusing similar shapes with symmetric shapes
teachingTips: Chart: shape and number of symmetry lines

description: Create symmetric figures by completing the other half

coreConcepts: Reflect points across line of symmetry
Each point and its reflection are same distance from line
commonMistakes: Not measuring distance from line correctly
Making designs that are not actually symmetric
teachingTips: Start with simple shapes on grid paper
Count squares from line of symmetry
Check work by folding or using mirror

description: Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction situations

coreConcepts: Understand problem context and what is happening
Identify what is changing (increasing or decreasing)
Write number sentence to match story
commonMistakes: Adding when should subtract (or vice versa)
Choosing operation based on keywords only
teachingTips: Act out problems with objects or students
Draw pictures to show the action
Identify: start amount, change, end amount

description: Solve compare problems to find the difference between quantities

coreConcepts: Compare two quantities to find how many more/less
Can use subtraction or addition to solve
Keywords: more than, fewer than, difference
teachingTips: Line up objects to show comparison
Bar model diagrams: draw and compare bars
Use comparison language: How many more? How many fewer?
Connect to real comparisons: heights, ages, collections

description: Solve problems where the ending amount is unknown

coreConcepts: Addition: joining, putting together → result grows
Subtraction: separating, taking away → result shrinks
teachingTips: Act out with objects: start with some, add/remove more
Most common problem type - build fluency

description: Solve problems where the amount of change is unknown

coreConcepts: Can use subtraction or missing addend
Think: What was added/removed to get from start to end?
teachingTips: Draw diagrams showing before and after
Use missing addend strategy: start + ? = end
Count up from start to end
Real contexts: grew taller, saved money, lost items

description: Estimate sums and differences using rounding and mental math

coreConcepts: Round numbers to make mental math easier
commonMistakes: Rounding all numbers same way regardless of context
Not understanding when estimation is appropriate
teachingTips: When do we need exact vs approximate answers?
Round to nearest 10, 100, etc. for easier computation

description: Use rounding to estimate sums and differences before calculating

coreConcepts: Add or subtract the rounded numbers mentally
Result is an estimate, not exact
Helps check if exact answer is reasonable
commonMistakes: Rounding after calculating instead of before
Using exact calculation when estimate requested
teachingTips: Use compatible numbers (easy to work with)

description: Use estimation to determine if answers are reasonable

teachingTips: Check: Is answer way too big or too small?
Decimal point errors show up clearly

description: Build fluency with number relationships and part-whole understanding

coreConcepts: Numbers can be broken into parts
teachingTips: Use number bond diagrams: circle with two parts
Practice: What goes with 7 to make 10?
Games: number bond flash cards, matching

description: Use make-ten strategy to add numbers efficiently

coreConcepts: Break apart one addend to make 10 first
Ten is a friendly landmark number
commonMistakes: Not seeing when strategy is helpful
teachingTips: Explicit steps: What do I need to make 10?

description: Use doubles facts and near doubles strategy for mental addition

commonMistakes: Adding 2 instead of 1 for near doubles
Confusing which fact to start with
teachingTips: Near doubles: "If I know this double, I know..."
Real contexts: pairs of socks, eyes, hands
